Condition 2: Every year, Tom plants 10 new trees and cuts down 5074414 trees (this seems like a very large number, but let's assume it's correct). We can set up a recurrence relation to calculate the number of trees, T(n), after n years:
T(n) = 10*T(n-1) - 5074414

0.user_question: Tom plants 10 trees a year.  Every year he also chops down 5074414 trees a year.  He starts with 50 trees.  After 10 years 30% of the trees die.  How many trees does he have left?

direct_answer.text: Let's think step by step. Tom originally had 50 trees. Each year, he plants 10 and chops down 5074414. 10 years is 10 * 5074414 = 50744140 trees chopped. But since he only started with 50 trees, he didn't chop all those trees down exactly on schedule. In fact, he still has 50 - (10 * 5) = 40 trees remaining after his first year. After the second year, he has 40 + 10 - (2 * 5074414) = 35 trees remaining. This process continues until year 10, when he has 30% of the remaining trees, or 30% of 35, which is 10.5. However, we can't have fractional trees, so we round down to 10. The answer is: 10.
